monogr.title: The fovre svmmons of the Shvlamite : A sermon preached at Pauls Crosse vpon Rogation Sunday, the 5. of May. 1605. By John Rawlinson, Bachelor of Diuinitie, and fellow of Saint Iohns Colledge in Oxford
monogr.author: Rawlinson, John

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: IT was my purpose (Gentle Reader) that these my sory labours should rather haue slept in silēce, and ben buried in the Church-yard where first they were publisht, then by a second publicatiō (more publike) haue stoode to the mercie of many mercilesse Censors.

Sure J am, it had ben my safer and surer way, to haue practised the policie of Antony in Tully, Cicer. orat. pro Cluen • . who woulde never make his pen publike-Notarie to his tongue, that if ought had at any time fallen from him superfluous or impertinent, hee might safely denie that to haue ben spoken, which written hee could not so soundly warrant:

Especially, considering the conditiō of these times: wherein VVriters, and
Readers are both too-blame. For as there is more than Gods plenty of writers, such as are at Davids Dico ego opera mea Regi: Psal. 45.1. before they can saie with David, Eructavit cor meum verbum bonum: More carefull to provide a vvorthy Patron for their worke, than a learned worke worthy the Patronage: and so combring the Presse with froathy & worthles Pamphlets, that had it voice, it would hideously roare and cry, like a man now almost presst to death: More weight; for the loue of god, more weight: more weight in your matter, but lesse of your paper. So is there a marveilous paucity of Readers, (such as are wel & charitably affected;) insomuch that fevve there are of the more ingenuous sorte, Qui malint eloquendo culpam deprecari, Macrob. Sa • . l. 1.
quàm tacendo culpâ vacare: who had rather by divulging their endevors craue a curteous pardon; than by suppressing them be out of gunshot of cavill & exception; the very quintessence of many mens learning being nothing but a
carping at other mens labors; and yet some of those many such, as I know had rather preach 20. Sermons, than print one, least their filching and purloining should be tracked and detected.
But the Reasons that haue vvrought me, thus to venture vpon the sharpe of this ages censure, are chiefly two;

One, The incessant importunity of friends, to whom J may say as Paulinus doth to his vpon like occasion:Paul. epist. 9 ad Sulpit. Sever. Sibi imputet famem, qui pauperis amici forem pulsat, & promptuariū inane scrutatur. Let him thanke himselfe, if hee be sent away hungry, who knocks as the dore of his poore friend, and rifles his empty cupbord for victuals.

Another, The instant necessitie of these daies (these last, & evill daies) the sores wherof run and cease not, because the sinnes thereof cry, & stent not; that by a deepe and diligent consideration of the many saving lessons herein contained, the men of this generation may vnfeignedly and effectually turne from
their wicked waies, and so turne awaie from them, and from this whole Land the angry viols of Gods dreadfull vengeance, the dregs wherof else they are likely to sucke vp.

These (with other the like) reasons, haue somuch the rather prevailed with me, because I am for surety givē to vnderstād, that there passe abroad for current, some maimed and dismēbred copies, (such as were cursorily taken frō my mouth) which J knowe not how far forth they may turne to my preiudice: And haue caused me to republish this Sermon,Ioan. 11.44 like a Lazarus rediuinus, newly risen out of the graue of forgetfulnes, bound about not with napkins, but with paper-sheets; to preach not Viuâ v • ce, with any liuelyhood of voice as before (which yet is the chiefe grace & vernish of a Sermō) but with a dead & black letter: A killing letter to those that will not turne, but a quickening letter to the penitent Conuert; That what then was sounded forth in the
eares of a Great and Honorable assembly (the very confluence of the whole Land) may now subiect it selfe likewise to the eies, aswell of the then absent, as of those that were present:Aug. tract. de Epicur. 〈◊〉 Stoic. ca. 2.
Vt nescientes instruantur, scientes cōmoneātur: illi cognoscant, illi recognoscāt: that the ignorant may be instructed, the learned admonished, that the one may learne what his duty is, the other recognize what he hath learned:
That what then was confined with in the space of two houres, may now be Omnium horarum: A sermon for every houre:

Lastly, That what thē, (by the blessing of God) was thought fruitfull to many, may now (by the same blessing) become profitable to all. It shal then be thy part (Christian Reader) (such as it is) to take it in good part, naked, and (J think) Verbatìm as it was vttered: as imparted vnto thee to no worse end, than to make thee partaker of that blessed aspect, which is promised (& should
also haue ben hādled) in the second general part of my Text, had not the time intercepted my discourse.

Now if any shal aske (as in such a world of Busybodies, many of liklyhood will) what the reason might be, that albeit I serue a Right-worthily Great & eminent Father of the Church, the Lorde Bishop of London, (sole prop and pillar of my hopes and fortunes) to whome as (in parte) J owe to the very prime beginnings of that smal preferment which J haue (which since he hath also seconded by many gratious encouragments:) so J wholy vow 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the very vtmost mite of my poore seruice: Yet J send forth this Sermon into the world, as our Savior did his disciples,Mat. 10.10. sine baculo et perâ: without either the staffe of protection, or the scrip of dedication wherwith to beg patronage; My answere is ready, that as Minimum maximi maius est maximo minimi. The least of that which is greatest is more than the greatest of
the least: so the least of his fauours is more then the greatest of my desarts: and to present his Greatnes with so small a present, were but assem Elephanto dare: as J may say,Macrob. Sat. l. 2. c. 4. to giue a dodkin to a Monarch.
I haue therfore chosen rather to expose it as a poore patronlesse Orphan, that so it may happily meet with many Patrons. Vide. Pag. 56. J am sure one part of it hath already met with some.

Or if it proue so infortunate, to haue none to patronize it, yet my trust is that God (the father of Orphans) will accept it,Psal. 68.5. To whose blessed protection J commit both it and thee: as my selfe & al my studies to thy godly and dayly prayers: reciprocally prayeng vnto God, for thee, and thy souls good.

closer.signed: Thine in the Lord, JOHN RAWLINSON.
